segments.text: ...and in keeping ourselves alive.
I guess essentially your entire career has been supported by NAACP.
Oh yes, absolutely.
I was, as I say, worked for Kuiper as a summer student and then as a graduate student on NASA money.
I was kept with student deferments from the Vietnam War because I was working in a university on NASA support.
And ever since, and now, of course, I'm a NASA employee.
How do you think NASA has managed this?
I mean, have they understood what's going on in planetary astronomy?
Or have they tried to overmanage, micromanage, whatever?
Or have they done a reasonably good job?
Well, they've done all of those things because they've tried it all ways.
And in many respects, it has been done very well.
The main problem, I think, is that because modern planetary science is a child of
of NASA and government funding, it has not found its way in fully legitimate ways into American academic circles.
There are not enough planetary science positions in faculties in the universities in the United States.
And this leaves planetary scientists in a very, very vulnerable position.
NASA, I think, has made minor and relatively ineffective efforts to
to put planetary science in legitimate academic institutions around the country, but it could have done and should have done and must do much more.

That is the real weakness in planetary science now, I think, is that as the government funding waxes and wanes, there is no adequate buffer in the American academic institutions to keep planetary science moderately comfortable.
Do you think planetary astronomy is part of astronomy?
Planetary astronomy, I think, is and should be considered part of astronomy.
And there was a time when I was less sure of that, maybe 10 years ago.

But the reason I'm adamant about it now is that it's clear to me that classical astronomy is moving toward the understanding of the formation and development of planetary systems in general, and ours in particular, and at the same time,

people with their training in planetary astronomy and planetary science are becoming more and more aware of the connection to the interstellar medium and the material that is formed there and incorporated into our solar system.

When we hold in our hands, for example, a carbonaceous meteorite, we are holding pre-solar material, material which is preserved largely intact from its formation and chemical evolution in the interstellar medium.

So there is a very natural connection in terms of materials that we can study, objects that we can look at between planetary astronomy, studies of our solar system, and studies of the interstellar medium.
Sorry, Gene, to interrupt it yesterday when they were trying to take your picture.
But I just told Dale here.
in the drawing, I got a piece of Allende.
You lucky dog.
I saw it come in.
Ed Barker and I were observing on the 82-inch.
It was a lot of serious.
He was standing on the catwalk, and I was down the road.
In Texas?
Yeah.
At McDonald's.
And you talk about the ignorant peasants being scared.
That thing, it was a coup d'etat run.
The moon was just two days past full.
that wiped it out.
And you could see the smoke.
It was like a crude oil tank blowing up.
And I ran up to Ed, and I said, it's got to be a carbonaceous chondrite.
I mean, he's right here.
You can ask him.
I said that.
But it looked like the Hindenburg going up, which was my first reaction.
And so I got a piece of it.
And I don't know who to tell except you characters.
Who would appreciate that?
Do you mind if we just, you can do your stuff and we'll just talk over here?
Sure.
Just finishing up an interview.
In the old days, there wasn't any Icarus.
There wasn't any division for planetary sciences.
And now planetary astronomers in this country have their own society and their own journal.
Do you think that's good or bad?
Well, I think it's good.
On the one hand, it has provided a medium for us to publish all the kinds of things that we do.
There is, of course, a downside to it.
And a quick illustrative point might be useful.
At the time that radio astronomy was developing as a kind of a separate discipline, there was some discussion as to whether or not the radio astronomers should have their own journal.
And Otto Struve, I believe, was the vociferous proponent of not having a separate journal.

and keeping astrophysics unified through the astrophysical journal, principally, and the astronomical journal, whether the results come from the radio part of the spectrum or the optical infrared part of the spectrum.
So that's a voice in favor of keeping things together.
However, because, and this is now a personal view, because of the animosity or the ambivalence, let's soften it a bit, too,

that we've already talked about between classical astronomers and planetary scientists, there has developed a kind of set of different standards to which research papers should be held for publication.
And I think that if the Astrophysical Journal were the only medium for the publication of planetary science papers, we would have a lot of problems getting some of our work published.
Not because it's intrinsically inferior in quality, but because it's different.
And some of our standards are a bit different.
Some of them are fully as rigorous as those to which classical astrophysicists hold their work.
Certainly superior in cosmology.
Perhaps, yes, I think so.
I've found myself apologetic about the quality of spectra that I've published and interpreted from time to time.
And then I occasionally see what my astrophysics colleagues are doing, and I feel less apologetic.
What do you think was the impact
of the fact that we have found no evidence for life anywhere else in the solar system.
Do you think that's really hurt funding, in particular Mars?
Oh, I don't think funding has been hurt by the lack of funding life elsewhere.
That seems to me to be quite a separate activity, endeavor, quite a separate philosophical issue to planetary science or to pure science.

I've become more and more aware in just the last few years that so much science policy in the United States is politically driven, motivated, and controlled that it's almost independent of the scientific merit of projects that we're trying to do.
This is certainly true of big science projects such as planetary exploration programs.
And most recently, the program for the search for extraterrestrial intelligence, which is such a politically charged issue.
And which has been funded out of existence, I guess.
In just recent weeks, it has been funded out of existence, at least at the moment.
But you see, that political wind can change directions very quickly and may again.
What do you think the public thinks about planetary astronomy?
Planetary astronomy in the public's view, I think, is a productive and exciting endeavor.
It's gotten a lot of press.
It's highly amenable to promotion by exciting results and pictures to go with it.
And it, in many ways, is the connection point between the public and astronomical science.
It seems to me that as a former teacher and as a person who talks publicly about science quite a bit, that the public has two points of connection with astronomy.
One is, what is a black hole, which is a question that comes up at nearly every contact with a layperson.
And what are the planets made out of, or some other question of comparable interest specifically to solar system things.

And I'd like to punctuate that by noting that projects which are primarily classical astrophysics in nature, such as the Hubble Space Telescope, get a tremendous amount of mileage out of their photographs of the planets.
And I think that's just fine.
I wish our astrophysics colleagues would acknowledge the value of planetary science, if only for its PR value in that respect.
That brings up a point that Oren Nix, who's a co-investigator on this, made in his book, Far Travelers.
And it was something that I saw when I was at headquarters, that the, quote, real, unquote, scientists did not want any pictures of
The theory being that if you could actually look at something and see right there that it wasn't real science.
Did you get that impression?
Well, maybe so.
Maybe so.
I'll go back to the issue of the composition of the surface of Triton and our detection of methane and nitrogen.
The detection of those chemicals on Triton's surface
essentially at the time that Voyager was launched in the late 70s, 1977.

Only over the next several years did it become apparent that Voyager was actually going to go to Triton and have a look at this object that I had been straining my eyes and telescopes to see for all those years and to get an up-close look.
Now, I had pretty much concluded to my satisfaction and the satisfaction of the other very few colleagues interested in the subject of what Triton Circus would look like when we got there.
But to then enjoy the extreme thrill of seeing it up close in my own lifetime, while it was still a topic of scientific interest and importance to me, was just about unparalleled.
It did not.
by having pictures of the surface of this object decrease or diminish its interest to me or to my colleagues in the slightest way.
And as I indicated, we've continued to observe this thing.
Even though we know in detail what its surface looks like, we've continued to observe it with ground-based telescopes where it remains an unresolved, faint, distant, cold point of light.
Now, how that attitude persists with classical astrophysicists who now can see
deep into the core of M31 with HST or deep into the cores of jetting galaxies and other objects of interest to astrophysicists?
I don't know.
I would hope that they haven't lost their interest and excitement in an object just because they can see it better.
What kind of a job do you think Planetary Astronomers have done of selling themselves to the public and to the Congress?
Planetary astronomers have not dealt well with Congress, in part because we are naive academics by nature and feel that politics and politicians are to be held at arm's distance.
And it's only been in the last 10 years that we as a profession have become aware of the necessity to deal with political people and political issues because we are a creation of a political entity.
namely the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, and are totally dependent on government funding.
People in the Congress have told us how naive we are and how aloof we have appeared to be.
On the one hand, depending on the Congress and public funding for our support of our expensive hobbies, and on the other hand, being unwilling to deal with politicians in a real way.
So planetary scientists have
have grown up a bit, I think, in the last decade or decade and a half through the necessity of having to deal with politics and politicians.
So that's probably to the good.
It isn't any fun.
And I particularly don't like it.
But it seems to be a fact of life.
I don't think we do it very effectively yet.
In terms of dealing with the public, I think we've done quite well.
The Voyager missions and all the press that
was attendant to those flybys, half a dozen of them, was a great experience, a great positive experience.
Pictures of the planets from Voyager appeared on the covers of national news magazines around the world.
Planetary scientists were interviewed.
I was interviewed.
And David Morrison and I, at the time that Pioneer went by Saturn, held what I think is the world's only, and certainly the first,
press conference devoted entirely to Saturn satellite Iapetus.
And so the public has gotten a dose of some rather arcane science through the successes of Voyager and Pioneer and Viking, of course, and Galileo, and we hope that that sequence will continue.
I think we've done well with the public, not so well with the politicians.

There's been a lot of attention in the past few years to making planetary astronomy a practical science, and there's been a lot of publicity, certainly, about killer asteroids, ozone hole, global warming, search for extraterrestrial intelligence.
I suppose that's good for getting money, but do you think it's been overdone a bit?
Well, I'm not sure it has been overdone.
No, I don't think it has yet.
And I'm not sure that there's any expectation that it will be overdone.

There is, of course, some concern about returning to the thrilling days of yesteryear when planetary science had a crazy element, or at least a perceived crazy element, namely the diversable lowell types.
And that could happen again if the crazies really did get a hold of these various topics.
Planetary scientists have done a pretty good job of keeping that from happening.
the issue of impacts on the Earth from comets and so on, has been promoted, discussed, and embellished by genuine scientists.

Eugene Shoemaker, David Morrison, Clark Chapman, and various other people have been writing at the popular level and testifying before Congress and dealing with NASA committees in a very professional way.
And this, I think, is what's keeping it from going crazy.
In the SETI era,
into things.
We have Jill Tarter, we have Frank Drake, we have Carl Sagan, all of whom are respected, very legitimate scientists dealing with these issues.
And if we can keep it on that plane, I think we can keep it under control.
What do you think the state of planetary astronomy is now?
Going up, going down, hanging in there?
Well, the state of planetary astronomy now here in the beginning of fiscal year 94 is continuing to decline in terms of
of the availability of public money for it.
The National Science Foundation supports it at a very, very low level.
And may not continue.
And may not continue.
NASA funding for planetary science is under continual attack, pressure, let's say, because of the cost of other NASA programs.
Yet the population of planetary scientists continues to increase.
And that's evidenced by the increased attendance of the Division for Planetary Sciences meetings
held every year.
And the quality of the work that comes out of those meetings continues to go up.
And young people are continually attracted to this field, in spite of the fact that the funding pressure and the pressure for other resources continues to grow.
So it's a peculiar situation.
And I think that the reason that the interest in it continues to grow is because of its intrinsic value, its intrinsic interest, and its intrinsic relevance to understanding
The Earth is a planet.
Somebody's getting their bachelor's degree, and they're interested in planetary astronomy.
What do you say to them?
I say that your prospects for getting a job and support are not particularly good.
But if you are driven to do this, for the same reasons that I was driven as a 13- or 14-year-old kid to do it, then go ahead.
Give it your best shot.
Well, that was actually the situation for astronomy in general when we were under Richard.
That's right, in a way.
We were not encouraged to go into astronomy because there was any sense of lucrative employment or even a guarantee of any job or anything of the kind.
And information distributed to random inquirers by the American Astronomical Society when I was a kid said such things as, there is very little room in astronomy for people of marginal ability.
And that's probably still true.
I consider myself a person of marginal ability, but I had super marginal persistence and dedication, and I had to become an astronomer.
And so I did, and I've been able to do it reasonably successfully.
Before there was even an NASA.
Before there was, yes.
And so I would tell a person in the situation you just described that if you have to do this, then you have to do it.
and somehow you and the rest of us will find a way.

And so when I find such a person with that kind of dedication and devotion, I do my very best to make them feel welcome in this profession, to help them both professionally and at the technical level, and try to get them involved, because that's where the discoveries will come from, is the people who are driven to do it.
The death of the Mars Observer Probe
to me at least, seem to come as a shock to a lot of people that have been in this field for only 10 or 20 years.
We both remember when failures of planetary and lunar probes were the norm rather than the exception.
Do you think this is a good slap in the face to wake some people up?
Well, in a way, it's a slap in the face in many respects.
Or a dash of cold water.
A dash of cold water.
It certainly shows that one can't be sanguine about the successes from complicated, expensive space probes.
The Vikings kind of worked, and the Voyagers kind of worked, and I think people got fat and happy.
Yes, we did.
One of the most serious elements of this now, of course, is that there are very few other
spacecraft programs that are flying or expected to fly in a reasonable amount of time.
Whereas in the 70s and 80s, there were programs under development more or less continuously, and at least the prospect of flying was not too remote or too distant.
So young people coming into the field, and also we were going to planets that were relatively close by and didn't take forever to get there.

So the situation is different now in that a person who has just been terminated in a funding sense by the failure of Mars Observer doesn't necessarily have any prospects on the immediate horizon to pick them up and to keep them actively employed and scientifically productive in the intervening years.
That's a very serious problem because some of these people will be forced to drift away into other fields just because of the lack of support.
There is no buffer program which can pick them up.
This is a leading question, and it calls for a personal answer.
I have heard it said at DPS meetings that we need planetary probes to keep the scientists interested.
And my very feeling always was that if the scientists were supposed to generate the interest themselves, whether they have probes or not.
Your comments?
Well, I tend to feel, as I think you do, that the intrinsic merit of this science will generate the interest on the part of people truly devoted to planetary studies, independent of the probes.
The probes provide the very, very important... Stuff that we otherwise couldn't get at all.
Things that we cannot do in any other way, that's true.
But we've already seen just a few days ago that...

work from essentially images of Mars from the distance of the Earth, taken in the proper way, in this case with the Hubble Space Telescope, but also from the ground, can still produce important science, despite the fact that we've been to Mars with a number of orbiters and two landers from the United States and so on.
So there's still a lot of work that can be done on the planets, but some of it simply cannot be done without probes.
Nonetheless, there are many compelling planetary problems
that will keep real scientists interested indefinitely into the future, even if there is never another planetary probe.

The field will shrink, of course, and there will be a smaller number of people doing it, but the people who are driven to understand the solar system, its nature, and its relationship to other systems of stars and dust and things in our galaxy and elsewhere will do this work no matter what.
One last and leading question.
I was going to say, what do you think, in the last 30 years, the greatest development in planetary astronomy has been?
But I'm reminded of the fact that when we were students, there were the gas giants and then there were the terrestrial planets.
And we didn't realize there's a whole different kind of planet, the ice planets and all that sort of stuff.
Do you think that is the most important thing we found out?
Or do you have your particular candidate?
I think it's very important that we've discovered that each planet is its own kind and that there is this vast collection of icy bodies in the outer solar system.
But I'm inclined to think that the most important realization is that it's a picture that's still evolving and emerging and a picture to which not all planetary scientists have yet signed up.
And that is our connection to interstellar
space to other material elsewhere in the galaxy.

I'm particularly impressed by the detection of organic material in the solar system, even in the inner solar system, that clearly had its origins on the grains of interstellar dust among the stars in the diffused interstellar medium.
This material, some of it has come into the solar system relatively unaltered, and we're just beginning to detect and understand that.
Other of that material has been highly altered, and we are some of that stuff.
